title: At close of business on 15 June 2022, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 4 May 2022?
preds: Fed is wanting to take money out of the economy

Fed signaled strongly and specifically that it will keep increasing the rates. Even if it slows down at this point, that could mean 0.25 given it signaled multiple .5 increases. The chances of enough happening in the next month to have them keeps things flat seems near-zero. It would likely require a huge pandemic wave or very painful recession that onset immediately.
JPow has already declared it's going to happen

https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/feds-racing-raise-rates-how-high-remains-an-open-bid-2022-04-28/ Fed Chair Jerome Powell said policymakers were ready to approve half-percentage-point rate hikes at upcoming policy meetings in June and July.
Seems like Powell is ready to hike again, only 50bps today so seems likely next now.
Might as well go all the way...
GDP contracted in Q1. I don't think Fed will reverse course in the next 45 days, but it's not impossible. I could see a stock market crash causing them to pause.

It continues to seem like the rate will increase at the next meeting, but the question is by how much and if that direction will continue. The fed says they will fight inflation even if the stock market reacts negatively to an increase, and perhaps they have the resolve to do that for 6 weeks, but I remain unconvinced there is no chance of them stalling for one meeting to slow the pace of increase. Dropping the chance of same from 30% to 20% but leaving it there - much higher than the crowd forecast - because of the fact that there are two major change points.

Interesting, given the 0.75-1.00 odds on 04MAY2022 being 30% and 0.75-1.00 odds on 15JUN2022 being 70%, I seem to be the only person assuming independence (= 30% x 70% chance = 21% the FOMC recommendation stays the same). In contrast, the crowd is betting 6% on same.
https://www.investing.com/central-banks/fed-rate-monitor
More comments by the Fed last week about how they could go faster if they wanted

Powell states that the FED plans to raise interest rates throughput 2022 regardless of what the stock market does. He has stated that if it comes between inflation and boosting the economy, that inflation is the higher priority. I don't believe this. Markets are already freaking out with the yield curve flattening in many areas. The stock market is solidly in correction territory. After one more rate hike if the Fed is still acting as if they plan to continue doing this I think the markets will strongly crash. Everything is broken so badly and the markets are so artificial it is very hard to predict what will happen. Actually, let me correct that, it is easy to know what will happen, it is hard to know when.
It's very clear that the Fed plans two more consecutive rate hikes.

Re-evaluating based on Powell's comments (fast) and Bullard's comments this AM (Faster as well). Seems like at least 25 in May (maybe 50bps) and then another 25 (maybe 50 now!) in June. From there I will begin to consider if they pause at some point (Maybe July?) but for now it seems they are keen to hike more aggressively. Bond market action seems relatively supportive. Despite an aggressive flattening of the 2Y10Y (may invert!) the 3M10Y is staying significantly higher. Suggests market is accepting the pace of hikes and is pricing in a "soft landing" (somewhat like 1994). So the only thing in my view that would stop the Fed's outlook would be a significant slowdown in the economy which appears unlike (for now, but let's have an eye on how bad energy/food prices get and if that impacts agg. demand).

Increasing confidence that the Fed goes at a 25bps clip over the coming months. Leaving some room for SAME if the Fed (per Waller's remarks today) hike 50bps in May, that could leave a gap (HOLD) in June.
Correction. Accidentally updated the wrong forecast.
Powell talked about 6 increases this year.
Fed made a smaller than expected increase. Likelihood of additional small increases throughout the year much much higher

Following 25bp increase today (Mar 16), FOMC indicates increases in rates likely at next meetings, into 2023 [1].  So chance of increase at next meeting seems highly likely.  Small chance that conditions change over the intervening weeks leading to increases to be delayed. [1] https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcprojtable20220316.htm
The latest dot plot seems to be expecting hikes at every meeting. https://twitter.com/LiveSquawk/status/1504156885951336455/photo/2

Given the Fed's move today and likelihood for a move 25bps in May, I suggest they'll continue bumping 25bps at each meeting. That said, I'm leavin some room for a HOLD given we may start seeing base effects in inflation and/or alleviations of supply chain problems / an increase in LFPR

This is actually a really tough one. I really don't see them getting five rate hikes this year. Everything will crash well before that and they will have to reverse course. But I'm not sure it will happen by June. My certainty is much higher than it actually is because I'm making up for a lower prediction earlier
Guesstimate is a hard lift in March and then slow to no for a few months
Increasing to reflect the higher target rate indicated for the summer.
Adjusting down on potential Ukraine related recession

If they do not, there will be acceleration of inflation.  With all the discussion about inflation, this has a compounding effect since people expect it.  Businesses already have stopped their concern about consumer backlash against price rises.  The fed does not want to act boldly when adjusting up, so they will ease into rate hikes until May and then be forced into more bold moves as the effects of the earlier rate hikes do not have desired effect.  They will also want to curb cyclical demand hikes as people go into the summer vacation period.
Lowering. It looks like there's an expectation of a big first raise, which would lower the likelihood of raise in June.

The real question is where is the Fed stock market put? How far will the FED let the stock market fall before they reverse course and stop raising rates?  The FED hasn't even done anything yet, all they have done is talk about it, and we already have some carnage. Investors are taking their money out of speculative growth stocks like Netflix and Tesla and that money is flowing into performance stocks and hard assets like real estate and gold. The Arkk fund is down 50%. Under the Taylor rule, if inflation is at7%, the federal funds rate should be at 8%. If the Fed truly thought the market was strong they would have raised rates a long time ago.  I expect them to raise rates in March and then all hell will break loose and that will be the last rate hike. If you're listening to what the FED is saying, keep in mind, the FED has not predicted an economic downturn in its entire existence of 108 years. Right before the Great depression they said they had defeated the business cycle. When we were already in a recession in 2007 bernanke went on the TV and said we were not heading into a recession and there was nothing to worry about. In 2009 bernanke said the quantitative easing purchases were temporary, and they were not monetizing the debt. Well guess what we still have all that debt on the books 13 years later. In 2018 Powell was wrong about being able to raise rates. In 2021 they said the inflation was transitory. If you still think the FED has credibility, well, you're wrong.
Updated based on the lastest number from FedWatch Tool.
expecting a hike at every meeting unless/until something new breaks
We will either see three consecutive hikes, or hikes in March and June. In any case, it's very likely that June is higher than May.

There is a FOMC meeting ending 04MAY22, and the next ends on 15JUN2022. So this question is just asking "Will The Fed announce an increase at the 14-15JUN22 Meeting. This survey pre-dates the 7.5 CPI publication, but it has 7 of 9 wall street banks predicting rates will rise in June vs. May.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-31/wall-street-economists-split-on-how-fast-and-far-fed-will-hike This calculator infers the derivatives markets' estimate of rate increases at each FOMC meeting: VERY useful. Assuming independence of May and June implied rate forecasts, there is only a 21% chance of rates staying the same. Markets are assuming 100% likelihood of 25bp+ hike in March2022, and a 100% likelihood of 25bp+ hike in May already.
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html
hikes in the first three meetings of the year seem almost certain and are fully priced in fed fund futures markets
50% chance of a rate increase at each meeting this year

Base rates 1. Fed has changed the target rate between early May and mid-June 6 times since 1990, which is 19% of the time. Estimates: Current projections are for around 4 rate increases this year and there are 7 meetings left this year, which is 57%... I'm not sure if they will change the rate at the end of the meeting or just announce that they will change it though. They could announce that it will change on May 5th and then not again at the June meeting. If they did this the "Yes" criteria would be satisfied... Good question. Averaging to 38% for a Higher and rest for the same. This feels low though. I'm upping to the Higher estimate to the base rate estimate of 57%. I will raise it again if nothing happens by May, and I will lower it if there is a big raise before then.
Oops, accidentally did this forecast for the wrong question 😋
At least 25 basis points each month.
+5 on a rate increase on inflation numbers being a little higher than expected.
Rate hikes are likely to be earlier in the year but may pause to allow data to inform next steps. Also withdrawal of federal fiscal support is being withdrawn rapidly.

With rising inflation I believe there there is 0% that fed funds rates will be cut however, depending on how effective is the March increase I feel it is more than probable that the upper limit fed funds rate will increase as I believe inflation will continue to rise in the near term
They will be data dependent.  Key data will not change much.
Record-high inflation is likely to take several months to control; current low unemployment suggests that there is room for further Fed action.
short period between May and June

The inflationary pressures will come with a lag (from energy cost-push) and lead to higher than expected inflation during the spring-time (inflation surprise) thus leading the FED to increase its target range.

On the related question about May vs March, I'm currently slightly betting on May being the same as March. However, that is based on my current belief that the market reaction to the hike may spook the Fed into delaying the next hike. However, if that is the case I don't think will put it off beyond June.  It's also of course possible that they do 3 consecutive hikes. I think that will be inflation dependent though. At the moment I think it's more likely to be higher in June.

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/07/business/economy/jobs-interest-rates-federal-reserve.html?campaign_id=2&emc=edit_th_20220108&instance_id=49813&nl=todaysheadlines&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=79071&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1 "The jobless rate is falling sharply and pay is jumping. That may increase the urgency as the Federal Reserve withdraws economic support.
. . . 
The combination of a healing job market and the threat that price increases will jump out of control has prompted central bankers to speed up their plans to withdraw policy help from the economy. Fed officials are already slowing the big bond purchases they had been using to support the economy. In addition to that, they could raise rates three times in 2022, based on their estimates, and economists think those increases could begin as soon as March. 
. . . 
And officials have signaled that once rate increases start, they could promptly begin to shrink their balance sheet — where they hold the bonds they have purchased to stoke growth throughout the pandemic downturn. Doing that would help to lift longer-term interest rates, reinforcing rate increases and helping to further slow lending and spending.
. . . 
Krishna Guha, an economist at Evercore ISI, argued that the combination of rapidly declining unemployment and heady wages might even prompt central bankers to increase interest rates faster than once every three months — the fastest pace in their last set of interest rate increases, which took place from 2015 to 2018. “The Fed might end up having to hike at a pace faster than the baseline one hike per quarter,” Mr. Guha wrote. Fresh data out next week could further intensify that pressure: The Consumer Price Index is expected to surge to 7 percent in the year through December, based on a Bloomberg survey of economists, which would be the fastest pace of increase since June 1982.

Consensus is that rates will be raised over and over this year along with "normalization" of QE, however as the shenanigans of payroll numbers become less tenable or revised lower, the hawkishness of the Fed will turn as rapidly as during normalization during 2019.
i have to be honest that I dont really understand how these work but inflation is very high and I think they will attempt to curb it
All signs indicate they will increase it to protect against inflation, but given the number of variables between now and then that could change, only assigning a 69% chance.
The bubble is starting to deflate even with the suggestion of future rate hikes. I don't see the market being strong enough for a second rate hike in June.
As it's still unclear what May will look like, I don't know if the second hike will come in June or not. It's also possible (but unlikely) to see three consecutive rate hikes.

The current target rate is 0.00 to 0.25. 0.25 is as low as it has been since 2010 -- this has been a historically low level. Therefore, I don't think the rate announced rate will be lower than it is today, although it depends where the upper range target rate is on May 4. At this point, I think the rate will either stay the same or go up. What I'm reading suggests that any policy changes are announced immediately, so I assume any policy changes made at the May meeting would be announced before close of business on June 15.

I'll start at "Lower" -- given the inflationary backdrop and messaging from the Fed, I find it unlikely that the Fed will seek to lower rates, when they have the opportunity to HOLD rates at already accomdative levels. Though can't rule out a significant black swan that leads to a lowering (5%). "SAME" -- may options here -- a 50bps raise in Mar that leaves May/June "SAME" because it did the job. a March 25 bps (or 50bps), May 25bps which does the job and June is fine.  "HIGHER" -- is my base case as I suspect the Fed doesn't waver from consensus and sticks to a 25bps per mtg for the first few meetings of the year as supply chain bottlenecks, labour issues, and energy prices continue to pressure inflation to the upside. That said, there's a chance the Fed hikes 50bps in Mar to "shock and awe" and then holds off May, realizes they're missing inflation and hikes again in June. I put this lower likelihood but it adds to the probability of HIGHER. Overall, at current levels of inflation, market pricing, and the Fed's messaging, I suspect a 25, 25, 25 pace to start the year and leads me to weight "HIGHER" more. That said, i can't rule out a 50bps in March (maybe 25 bps May) ruining the "HIGHER" party. Let's see how payrolls looks and ECI next month.

last major time that the upper rate increased (2017 to 2019) it went up every 2 or 3 meetings so would run this as base rate (it doesn't seem to be for reducing rampant inflation back then though)
So my options are: 
1 doesn't increase at all until June (bin 3)
2 increases in March with a possible increase in June (bin 3)
3 Increases in March and May so very unlikely for June (bin 2)
4 increases in May so unlikely to increase in June (bin 2) 1 seems possible but unlikely because they have signaled that moves are imminent
2 seems likely to me but possibly there will be a bigger gap at the start
3 feels quite unlikely based on historical increases
4 seems quite likely and more so if there is no change in March

Great question.  Dates of meetings between now and and May 14 also include March, May and June.   So three meetings.   I believe the upper bound will be raised in March.  traditionally the fed has moved every other meeting, yet the fed is trying to become more aggressive, so the question also asks will the rate be raised in May?  If there is no raise in May, the June will likely be higher.   On the other hand if the the Fed is trying to be aggressive, they could raise three meetings in a row.   I believe that there will be a raise in March and June.  Therefore the upper bound should be higher on Jun 15 compared to my forecasted upper bound from March and a hold in May.

Still hoping to see many incremental adjustments rather than big shocks.
Expecting increase in March will check
Possibly in May
if not in one of those then will increase probability

Inflationary pressures mean likelihood of an upward trend but a month to month rise is unlikely so the chances of a rate rise specifically in the time period highlighted is low. The chances of any rate reductions this year seem very low

Tough one for me, I know nothing about US monetary policy. Inflation is pretty high and employment strong, I don't think that Covid is going to impact this in a major way, so there seems no reason not to try and drop inflation
The stage has been set for an increase
https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/26/the-fed-sets-the-stage-for-a-rate-hike-heres-what-that-means-for-you.html

Chairman Powell recently testified that inflation is a growing threat, and Goldman in the last several day predicted four adjustments in 2022.  Inflation will continue as oil, real estate and food prices rise.  Omnicron appears to be fading, however, and supply chain issue are declining, which may reduce inflationary pressures by mid-year.

I'm leaning toward increases in March and June. I think March, May, and June is very unlikely, maybe 10% chance of that happening, and March, May, but not June is unlikely, maybe 20% chance. Not March, May, and not June also seems somewhat unlikely now, probably another 20% chance.
I don't think the rate would lower anymore. Depends on market, they mat keep it same or go little higher but they won't go lower.
Inflation should remain rather sticky well into 2022 and into 2023.
Depends on the size of the initial increase(s). They might try to surprise the markets with fewer and bigger increases.
they may want to take a cautious approach rather than many rapid fire raises
The Fed has all but guaranteed that they will be lifting rates in March and potentially every month through the rest of the year. I don't seem much on the horizon that would change their position.

On the basis that Powell is ready to raise rates at March 15-16 meeting, it is very likely there will be at least one rate hike this year.  However, between May 4 to June 15, 2022, it is unlikely the Fed will change their views drastically unless actual inflation reported during this period is higher than anticipated.
